elements.title: History of Value Creation—Toshiba’s DNA & Corporate Timeline

data.value: Toshiba’s origins can be traced back to the late 19th century with Hisashige Tanaka (founder of Tanaka Engineering Works, later Shibaura Engineering Works) and Ichisuke Fujioka (founder of Hakunetsu-sha). Historical timeline highlights include: founding of Tanaka Engineering Works (1873), establishment of Hakunetsu-sha (1890), Japan’s first electric washing machines and refrigerators (1930), merger forming Tokyo Shibaura Denki (1939), world's first automated mail processing equipment (1967), Japan’s first word processor (1978), commercialization of the world’s first laptop PC (1985), and the introduction of the world's first NAND flash memory (1991).

Toshiba’s technological breakthroughs not only revolutionized household appliances such as electric rice cookers and washing machines but also paved the way for modern computing with advances in word processing, portable computing, and semiconductor memory.
The longstanding motto 'Committed to People, Committed to the Future' underscores Toshiba’s dedication to societal betterment through innovative business practices and technological advancement.
